name: Literary Titles Explained Quiz | Literary Titles | 10 Questions

questions.text: 'The Old Man and the Sea' is one of Hemingway's best-known works. Who is the 'old man'?
questions.explanation:
Santiago.

	Simple fisherman. Vanya is from Chekhov, Joad is from Steinbeck, Benjy is from Faulkner.

questions.text: Camus is famous for 'The Stranger'. What was the stranger's name?
questions.explanation:
Meursault.

	Classic. Roderigo is from Shakespeare, Kurtz is from Conrad, Jude is from Hardy.

questions.text: Hesse may be best known for 'Steppenwolf'. What was this character's name?
questions.explanation:
Harry Haller.

	Demian and Knecht are from other works by {Hesse;} Fagin is from Dickens.

questions.text: Dostoevsky wrote 'The Idiot'? Who was the 'idiot'?
questions.explanation:
Myshkin.

	Raskolbikov is from 'Crime and Punishment,' Vronsky is from Tolstoi, Valjean is from Hugo.

questions.text: Thornton Wilder wrote 'Our Town'. What was the name of the town?
questions.explanation:
Grover's Corners.

	In New Hampshire, I believe.

questions.text: Inge wrote 'Come Back, Little Sheba'. Who was Sheba?
questions.explanation:
A dog.

	Little Sheba never will come back.

questions.text: Thomas Hardy wrote 'The Mayor of Casterbridge'? What was the mayor's name?
questions.explanation:
Michael Henchard.

	Mellors was 'Lady Chatterley's Lover'. Webber is from Thomas {Wolfe;} Whiteside is 'The Man Who Came to Dinner'.

questions.text: Arthur Miller wrote 'Death of a Salesman'. Who was the salesman?
questions.explanation:
Willy Loman.

	His best known work. Cassio is from Shakespeare, Flood is from Inge, Kowalski is from Tennessee Williams.

questions.text: Charles Dickens wrote 'A Tale of Two Cities'. Which two cities?
questions.explanation:
London, Paris.

	'It was the best of times ...'

questions.text: Who is NOT one of the 'Three Musketeers'?
questions.explanation:
D'Artagnan.

	The novel may be about him - but he's not one of the three.
